caption: Figure 2

Estimation error ratios ∥θ^−θ∗∥2/∥θ^naive−θ∗∥2subscriptdelimited-∥∥^𝜃superscript𝜃2subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript^𝜃naivesuperscript𝜃2\lVert\widehat{\theta}-\theta^{*}\rVert_{2}/\lVert\widehat{\theta}^{\text{naive}}-\theta^{*}\rVert_{2} in dependence of the pre-factor C𝐶C appearing in the tuning parameter λ𝜆\lambda.

In alignment with Theorem 1, the regularization parameter λ𝜆\lambda is chosen as λ=C⋅σy⋅log⁡(n+d)n𝜆⋅𝐶subscript𝜎𝑦𝑛𝑑𝑛\lambda=C\cdot\sigma_{y}\cdot\sqrt{\frac{\log(n+d)}{n}}, where C𝐶C is referred to as “pre-factor” and σysubscript𝜎𝑦\sigma_{y} is a
calibration factor depending on the distribution of the response. The calibration factor is chosen as an approximation of the expected standard deviation of the response variables {yi}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑖1𝑛\{y_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}, where the expectation is taken with respect to the random predictors333This expectation is evaluated using numerical integration, approximating the linear predictor by a N​(β0∗,∥β∗∥22)𝑁superscriptsubscript𝛽0superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝛽22N(\beta_{0}^{*},\lVert\beta^{*}\rVert_{2}^{2})-random variable justified by the central limit theorem.. The use of
σysubscript𝜎𝑦\sigma_{y} is motivated by results on linear regression in [23] and an analysis of the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-estimation error for ξ∗superscript𝜉\xi^{*} if β∗superscript𝛽\beta^{*} were known (omitted for space reasons). In practice, σysubscript𝜎𝑦\sigma_{y} can be approximated by taking the average of the variance function
of the corresponding GLM evaluated at the {yi}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑖1𝑛\{y_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}; in order to enable Figure 2 that is specifically dedicated to the selection of λ𝜆\lambda, the factor σysubscript𝜎𝑦\sigma_{y} is fixed so that it does not vary across different randomly generated data sets.

is varied over a logarithmically spaced grid. When presenting the results in Figures 3 and 4, we display the oracle
selection of λ=λ​(C)𝜆𝜆𝐶\lambda=\lambda(C) minimizing ∥θ^​(λ)−θ∗∥2subscriptdelimited-∥∥^𝜃𝜆superscript𝜃2\lVert\widehat{\theta}(\lambda)-\theta^{*}\rVert_{2} as well as the range of a quantity of interest for C∈[CLower,CUpper]𝐶subscript𝐶Lowersubscript𝐶UpperC\in[C_{\text{Lower}},C_{\text{Upper}}], where
CLowersubscript𝐶LowerC_{\text{Lower}} and CUppersubscript𝐶UpperC_{\text{Upper}} are fixed numbers. The resulting upper and lower bounds
over this range are complemented by confidence bars with height 5×5\times standard error. Figure 2 displays explicitly how the (normalized) estimation error ∥θ^−θ∗∥2/∥θ^naive−θ∗∥2subscriptdelimited-∥∥^𝜃superscript𝜃2subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript^𝜃naivesuperscript𝜃2\lVert\widehat{\theta}-\theta^{*}\rVert_{2}/\lVert\widehat{\theta}^{\text{naive}}-\theta^{*}\rVert_{2} depends on the choice of C𝐶C; the division by ∥θ^naive−θ∗∥2subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript^𝜃naivesuperscript𝜃2\lVert\widehat{\theta}^{\text{naive}}-\theta^{*}\rVert_{2} with θ^naivesuperscript^𝜃naive\widehat{\theta}^{\text{naive}} defined under “naive” makes the results interpretable across different settings.

The above three approaches are evaluated in terms of their ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-estimation error for the
regression parameter, i.e., ∥βest−β∗∥2subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝛽estsuperscript𝛽2\lVert\beta^{\text{est}}-\beta^{*}\rVert_{2}, and the deviance (Kullback-Leibler divergence) between μ∗=𝐄⁡[𝐲∗|𝐱]superscript𝜇𝐄conditionalsuperscript𝐲𝐱\mu^{*}=\operatorname{\mathbf{E}}[\mathbf{y}^{*}|\mathbf{x}] and μest=(h​(𝐱i⊤​βest))i=1nsuperscript𝜇estsuperscriptsubscriptℎsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖topsuperscript𝛽est𝑖1𝑛\mu^{\text{est}}=\big{(}h(\mathbf{x}_{i}^{\top}\beta^{\text{est}})\big{)}_{i=1}^{n}, where we recall that h​(⋅)ℎ⋅h(\cdot) denotes
the response function in GLMs. The notation βestsuperscript𝛽est\beta^{\text{est}} represents a placeholder for any of the three estimators introduced above. The results shown in Figures 2, 3, and 4 are averages over the 100 replications obtained for each setting.

Figure 2 confirms that as the pre-factor C𝐶C increases, the error ratio approaches one as expected since θ^→θ^naive→^𝜃superscript^𝜃naive\widehat{\theta}\rightarrow\widehat{\theta}^{\text{naive}} as C𝐶C grows. Second, we note that the error ratio increases sharply beyond one as C→0→𝐶0C\rightarrow 0; this corresponds to a regime of overfitting. Note that as C→0→𝐶0C\rightarrow 0 the proposed approach effectively yields an over-parameterized model achieving perfect fit on a given data set. This in agreement with Theorem 1 which requires a lower bound on λ𝜆\lambda for its results to hold. Figure 2 indicates
that C∈[0.2,1]𝐶0.21C\in[0.2,1] typically yields satisfactory results independent of the specific setting
or the specific distribution of the response variable.

Figure 2 displays explicitly how the (normalized) estimation error ∥θ^−θ∗∥2/∥θ^naive−θ∗∥2subscriptdelimited-∥∥^𝜃superscript𝜃2subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript^𝜃naivesuperscript𝜃2\lVert\widehat{\theta}-\theta^{*}\rVert_{2}/\lVert\widehat{\theta}^{\text{naive}}-\theta^{*}\rVert_{2} depends on the choice of C𝐶C; the division by ∥θ^naive−θ∗∥2subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript^𝜃naivesuperscript𝜃2\lVert\widehat{\theta}^{\text{naive}}-\theta^{*}\rVert_{2} with θ^naivesuperscript^𝜃naive\widehat{\theta}^{\text{naive}} defined under “naive” makes the results interpretable across different settings.

The above three approaches are evaluated in terms of their ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-estimation error for the
regression parameter, i.e., ∥βest−β∗∥2subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝛽estsuperscript𝛽2\lVert\beta^{\text{est}}-\beta^{*}\rVert_{2}, and the deviance (Kullback-Leibler divergence) between μ∗=𝐄⁡[𝐲∗|𝐱]superscript𝜇𝐄conditionalsuperscript𝐲𝐱\mu^{*}=\operatorname{\mathbf{E}}[\mathbf{y}^{*}|\mathbf{x}] and μest=(h​(𝐱i⊤​βest))i=1nsuperscript𝜇estsuperscriptsubscriptℎsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖topsuperscript𝛽est𝑖1𝑛\mu^{\text{est}}=\big{(}h(\mathbf{x}_{i}^{\top}\beta^{\text{est}})\big{)}_{i=1}^{n}, where we recall that h​(⋅)ℎ⋅h(\cdot) denotes
the response function in GLMs. The notation βestsuperscript𝛽est\beta^{\text{est}} represents a placeholder for any of the three estimators introduced above. The results shown in Figures 2, 3, and 4 are averages over the 100 replications obtained for each setting.

Average estimation errors for the regression parameter are shown in Figure 3. Shaded areas are used to represent the error range the for the proposed approach in dependence of the pre-factor C𝐶C: the upper and lower margins of the shaded areas represent the maximum and minimum error over C∈[0.1,2]𝐶0.12C\in[0.1,2], while the dashed lines outside the shaded areas indicate
±plus-or-minus\pm5 ×\times standard error. Overall, Figure 3 shows that the proposed estimator
can achieve substantial improvements over the naive estimator in a variety of settings. The extent
of the improvement generally increases with the fraction of mismatches and the signal level as measured by ∥β∗∥2subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝛽2\lVert\beta^{*}\rVert_{2}. For example, in the Poisson case the proposed approach with
optimally calibrated λ𝜆\lambda roughly achieves a three-fold reduction in average estimation error over the naive solution when ∥β∗∥2=1subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝛽21\lVert\beta^{*}\rVert_{2}=1, whereas a five-fold to six-fold reduction is achieved when ∥β∗∥2=2subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝛽22\lVert\beta^{*}\rVert_{2}=2. Despite the improvements that are obtained, the performance of the proposed estimator is still somewhat far from the oracle, specifically as k/n𝑘𝑛k/n increases, which indicates a potential for further reductions in error.

The results shown in Figure 4 concerning the deviance between μ∗superscript𝜇∗\mu^{\ast} and μestsuperscript𝜇est\mu^{\text{est}} as explained above agree with what is expected based on the results
for the estimation error in Figure 3. Again, the results indicate a dependence
of the improvement achieved by the proposed estimator on the signal level and the fraction of mismatches.

references:
Binary response. We now address the case of binary logistic regression. Note that this case behaves differently
from the three distributions for the response considered above, including binomial response with a significant number of trials: it is clear that a massive number of samples is required in order to estimate β∗superscript𝛽\beta^{*} accurately from binary response if ∥β∗∥2subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝛽2\lVert\beta^{*}\rVert_{2} is large; at the same time, if ∥β∗∥2subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝛽2\lVert\beta^{*}\rVert_{2} is small, the separation between the two classes corresponding to the two values
of the response variable is weak and thus the inherent noise is scarcely distinguishable from mismatch error in the response variable, which amounts to what has been extensively studied in the machine learning literature under the terms “label noise” (e.g., [58]). For this reason, we adopt the simulation setup above with sufficiently strong signal, i.e., ∥β∗∥2∈{4,6,8}subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝛽2468\lVert\beta^{*}\rVert_{2}\in\{4,6,8\} while β0∗=2superscriptsubscript𝛽02\beta_{0}^{*}=2, but the three competitors are evaluated only in terms of the deviance between μ∗superscript𝜇\mu^{*} and μestsuperscript𝜇est\mu^{\text{est}}.
Figure 5 shows that the proposed approach achieves improvements over the naive estimator, but the improvements are less pronounced than for the three other settings. The observed moderate improvement is in alignment with what is reported in the paper
[44] that studies the empirical performance of the proposed estimator exclusively in the setting of binary response with noisy labels.

caption: Figure 6

Hamming distance between π^​(β∗)^𝜋superscript𝛽\widehat{\pi}(\beta^{*}) and π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*} (on a log10(⋅+ϵ)\log_{10}(\cdot+\,\epsilon) scale with ϵ=0.001italic-ϵ0.001\epsilon=0.001), averaged over 1000 replications. Different curves correspond to different random design.
references:
In light of Theorem 3, permutation recovery
can be achieved if and only if ∥β∗∥2subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝛽2\lVert\beta^{*}\rVert_{2} is large enough, and specifically for Poisson case, if in addition β0∗/∥β∗∥2superscriptsubscript𝛽0subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝛽2\beta_{0}^{*}/\lVert\beta^{*}\rVert_{2} exceeds a certain threshold. Figure 6 confirms this qualitatively. In particular, we observe that the ratio β0∗/∥β∗∥2superscriptsubscript𝛽0subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝛽2\beta_{0}^{*}/\lVert\beta^{*}\rVert_{2} is crucial in the Poisson case unlike the other cases. Furthermore, we note that the distribution of the design does not have a significant impact on the results: all three random design can achieve (at least approximate) permutation recovery given sufficient signal as quantified by ∥β∗∥2subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝛽2\lVert\beta^{*}\rVert_{2}. Finally, note that for the Gamma distribution, recovery results improve as the shape parameter ν𝜈\nu increases.

caption: Figure 7

Left: 2-D histogram of the response variable before and after linkage resulting based on 100 random permutations. Right: Scatterplots of the response variable before and after linkage for four selected permutations.
references: In order to mimic mismatch error introduced by record linkage, the response variable (count) is put into a separate file that additionally contains varying combinations of variables that are used for record linkage (see below for a list of those combinations). In order to enforce one-to-one linkage, ties between potentially matching records given the variables used for matching are broken uniformly at random; in order to account for that randomness, we consider 100 independent replications, and the results reported subsequently represent averages over those replications unless noted otherwise. Put differently, the underlying random permutations Π∗superscriptΠ\Pi^{*} are of the block form Π∗=bdiag​(Π1∗,…,ΠK∗)superscriptΠbdiagsubscriptsuperscriptΠ1…subscriptsuperscriptΠ𝐾\Pi^{*}=\text{bdiag}(\Pi^{*}_{1},\ldots,\Pi^{*}_{K}), where K𝐾K denotes the number of unique combinations of values assumed for the matching variables. The average fraction of mismatches k/n𝑘𝑛k/n obtained in this way approximately equals 0.230.230.23. Figure 7 illustrates the discrepancy between actual response and response after linkage based on the following combination of matching variables: month, holiday, weekday, workingday, temp555temp denotes the temperature in degree Celsius on a given day (integer-valued).. In practice, the combination of variables used for matching may not be (fully) disclosed to the data analyst that operates on the merged data. Therefore, in addition to the case in which the matching variables are fully known, we also consider cases in which only one or two of the matching variables out of five overall are known (cf. Table 6).
